did.abstract: Jonas M. Goldberg was an NYU student studying Latin during Fall 1917 and Spring 1918 semesters. Ernest G. Sihler (1853-1942) was a professor of classics and Latin at New York University from 1892 to 1923. The Jonas M. Goldberg Notebook (1917-1919) was initially used by Jonas M. Goldberg as an assignment notebook for his Latin 10 class during the Fall 1917 and Spring 1918 semesters at New York University. In 1919, the notebook was reused by Goldberg's Latin professor, Ernest G. Sihler, to write a manuscript titled "Emperor Julian and His Religion."

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated in 1992. The accession number associated with this accession is 92.012.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note on Jonas M. Goldberg
bioghist.p: Jonas M. Goldberg was registered in University College in 1917. He took a Latin class during the Fall of 1917 and Spring 1918. He lived in an apartment building on the University Heights campus at 123 West 183rd St.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note on Ernest G. Sihler
bioghist.p: Ernest G. Sihler was a professor of classics and Latin at New York University from 1892 to 1923.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: It was surmised that the second half of the notebook was written by Ernest G. Sihler, who taught Latin 10 in the Fall of 1917. This is confirmed at the bottom of an undated Goldberg page where the instructor wrote, "This last you latinzed quite successfully. EGS" This is the same handwriting from the notes in the second half of the notebook on "Emperor Julian and His Religion".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This notebook was initially owned by NYU student Jonas M. Goldberg and contains his handwritten Latin 10 class assignments for the Fall 1917 and Spring 1918 semesters. The second half of the notebook contains 25 pages of a handwritten manuscript by Goldberg's Latin professor, Ernest G. Sihler titled "The Emperor Julian and His Religion."
